items.title: This CIA plot has shaped the US relationship with Iran for decades
items.description: Protesters are urging US President Donald Trump to help dismantle Iran's theocracy. If he answers the call, it won't be the first time the US government has toppled an Iranian government.

items.description: Camps offering intensive weight loss programs are on the rise in China as the country faces skyrocketing obesity rates.

items.title: Liberal election autopsy delayed after Dutton suggests report defamatory
items.description: The report, co-authored by Liberal grandees Pru Goward and Nick Minchin, has now been sent to a legal team to ensure it is watertight while the party decides what step to take next.

items.title: US House committee accuses South Africa of threatening national security

featured_image.name: US Ratchets Up Criticism of South Africa After BRICS War ...

items.description:
The United States has intensified its condemnation of South Africa following the "Will for Peace 2026" naval exercises that concluded on Friday off Cape Town's coast, with the House Committee on Foreign Affairs accusing Pretoria of undermining American national security. The criticism comes one day after the US Embassy in South Africa publicly lambasted the country for allowing Iran to participate in the drills alongside Chinese and Russian vessels.[1][2]

The week-long exercises, which ran from January 9 to 16, brought together naval forces from Iran, China, Russia, South Africa, and the United Arab Emirates, along with observers from Brazil, Ethiopia, Indonesia, and Egypt. The drills are described by South African officials as part of the BRICS Plus framework aimed at enhancing maritime security.[3][4][5]

items.title: Putin's 'worst-case scenario' could be realised in Iran regime change
items.description: Tehran is the epicentre of the nightly protests shaking Iran's regime, but the reverberations are being felt loud and clear in Moscow, too.

items.title: Charging board or rent to adult children can help them and you
items.description: Experts on the benefit of charging board and expenses if you’re sharing a home with young adults, and how to calculate it.

items.title: Surgery on board a hospital ship gave Amara his childhood back
items.description: On the largest civilian hospital ship in the world, Australian volunteers provide life-changing healthcare that is transforming lives.

items.title: China breaks ground on world's first hybrid nuclear plant for petrochemicals

featured_image.name: China starts construction of innovative nuclear project ...

items.description:
China has begun construction of the world's first large-scale nuclear power plant designed to directly supply industrial steam to the petrochemical sector, marking a new approach to decarbonizing heavy industry.

On Friday, workers poured the first concrete for the nuclear island of Unit 1 at the Xuwei Nuclear Heating and Power Plant in Lianyungang, Jiangsu Province, according to China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC), the state-owned developer. The project is the first nuclear power unit to break ground in the opening year of China's 15th Five-Year Plan, which runs from 2026 to 2030.[1][2][3]

items.title: Calls for NSW police to end protest restrictions before Australia Day rallies
items.description: Lawyers, human rights advocates and civil libertarians are urging the NSW Police Commissioner not to extend a ban on authorised public assemblies as January 26 approaches.

items.title: Labor to cut racial vilification offence from hate speech bill after Greens signal opposition
items.description: The Albanese government will separate laws tightening gun control from its proposed hate speech reforms after the omnibus bill failed to secure the support of the Coalition and the Greens.

items.title: Malaysia says Grok ban won't lift until X proves misuse 'will no longer occur'

featured_image.name: Malaysia blocks Grok amid uproar over nonconsensual sexualised ...

items.description:
Malaysia and Indonesia have become the first countries in the world to block access to Elon Musk's AI chatbot Grok after regulators determined the tool was being used to generate sexually explicit and nonconsensual deepfake images, including content depicting women and minors.

Indonesia's Ministry of Communication and Digital Affairs ordered restrictions on January 10, with Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia Commission following on January 11. The bans came after officials in both countries concluded that safeguards implemented by xAI, the company behind Grok, had failed to stop the spread of obscene content on X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Scientists open world's first ice core sanctuary in Antarctica

featured_image.name: As global warming melts glaciers, a novel sanctuary in Antarctica is ...

items.description: In a week of advances for polar science, researchers have unveiled the most detailed map ever created of Antarctica's hidden bedrock while a separate team inaugurated the world's first ice core sanctuary on the frozen continent, both efforts aimed at understanding and preserving climate data before it disappears.

items.title: OpenAI to begin testing ads in ChatGPT's free tier

featured_image.name: ChatGPT ads are coming, OpenAI leak suggests

items.description:
OpenAI announced Friday it will begin testing advertisements in ChatGPT, a major shift for the artificial intelligence company as it seeks to diversify revenue beyond subscriptions amid mounting operational costs.

The ads will roll out to users of the free version of the chatbot as well as those subscribing to ChatGPT Go, the company's newly launched budget-tier subscription that is becoming available globally at around $8 per month, according to The Wall Street Journal and Bloomberg. The move comes as OpenAI faces pressure to monetize its massive user base, with only about 5% of ChatGPT's 800 million weekly active users paying for subscriptions.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: OpenAI to test ads in ChatGPT for the first time

featured_image.name: OpenAI to Begin Testing Ads in ChatGPT in Push for Fresh ...

items.description:
OpenAI announced this week it will begin testing advertisements in ChatGPT for the first time, marking a pivotal shift for the artificial intelligence company as it seeks new revenue streams amid mounting financial pressures.

According to OpenAI's official statement, the company will start testing ads in the U.S. in the coming weeks, limited to users of the free tier and the newer $8-a-month ChatGPT Go plan. Ads will appear at the bottom of responses when a sponsored product or service is relevant to the conversation, and will be clearly labeled as such. Users of premium tiers including Plus, Pro, Business, and Enterprise will not see advertisements.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: NASA to roll out SLS rocket for first crewed Moon mission in 50 years

featured_image.name: The Artemis II rocket is rolling out this weekend. Watch live as NASA ...

items.description:
NASA is set to begin rolling out its towering Space Launch System rocket and Orion spacecraft for the Artemis II mission as early as Saturday morning, marking the final preparatory steps before the first crewed voyage to the Moon in more than half a century.

The rollout from the Vehicle Assembly Building to Launch Pad 39B at Kennedy Space Center in Florida is targeted to begin no earlier than 7 a.m. EST on January 17, according to NASA. The 322-foot rocket will travel approximately 6.4 kilometers over the course of up to 12 hours aboard the agency's crawler-transporter-2.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Interstellar comet's alien dust unlike anything in our solar system

featured_image.name: Comet 3I/ATLAS is back, and brand new images show its tail is ...

items.description:
The interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS continues to defy expectations, maintaining active outgassing and shedding material with a chemical composition unlike anything found in our solar system—even as it recedes toward the outer reaches of space.

A ground-based telescope in Hawaii captured the object on January 14, 2026, revealing a compact nucleus surrounded by a structured coma and the early formation of a tail, despite the comet being approximately 300 million kilometers from Earth. At such distances, most small bodies would fade into obscurity, yet 3I/ATLAS remains visible and active.[1][2]

items.title: Zelensky rejects Trump's claim that Ukraine is blocking peace

featured_image.name: Trump says Zelensky is holding up peace deal

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy firmly rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's assertion that Ukraine is obstructing peace negotiations, declaring that his country "has never been and will never be an obstacle to peace" while pointing to ongoing Russian attacks on civilian infrastructure as evidence of Moscow's true intentions.

The dispute erupted after Trump told Reuters on January 15 that Russian President Vladimir Putin is "ready to make a deal" while characterizing Ukraine as "less ready." When asked why U.S.-led negotiations had failed to end the nearly four-year-old conflict, Trump responded with a single word: "Zelenskyy."[1][2][3]

items.title: US and Taiwan reach trade deal cutting tariffs, securing chip investment

featured_image.name: TSMC, the Chip Giant, Is to Spend $100 Billion in U.S. Over the Next ...

items.description:
The United States and Taiwan have reached a trade agreement that will reduce tariffs on Taiwanese goods from 20 percent to 15 percent and secure hundreds of billions of dollars in semiconductor investment commitments, according to officials familiar with the matter. The deal, which the White House was set to announce Thursday, places Taiwan on equal footing with Japan and South Korea, which secured similar arrangements last year.[1][2]

Under the agreement, Taiwanese semiconductor companies will commit to a $500 billion increase in financing for American operations, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. pledging to build at least five additional fabrication plants in Arizona, effectively doubling its manufacturing presence in the state.[2][3][1]

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].
